docs.title: Welcome to YOLO-ONNX.
docs.text: YOLO-ONNX is a Python library for running YOLO models in ONNX format using the Ultralytics framework. It simplifies model loading, inference, and deployment across various platforms, including CPUs, GPUs, and edge devices.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Easy Model Loading: Load YOLO models in ONNX format with minimal setup.
  • Ultralytics Integration: Leverage Ultralytics' powerful YOLO11 models.
  • Flexible Inference: Run inference with customizable confidence and IoU thresholds.
  • Cross-Platform: Compatible with multiple hardware accelerators.

docs.title: Get Started
docs.text:
• Installation Guide
  • Quickstart Tutorial
  • Run Your First Inference

docs.title: License
docs.text:
YOLO-ONNX is licensed under the MIT License. See the full LICENSE file for details.

Note: YOLO models from Ultralytics are licensed under AGPL-3.0, which requires derivative works to be open-source. For commercial use, consider an Ultralytics Enterprise License.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Follow these steps to install YOLO-ONNX.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.8 or higher
  • pip

docs.title: Install via pip
docs.text:
pip install yolo-onnx

## Install from Source
1. Clone the repository:
   ```bash
   git clone https://github.com/your-username/yolo-onnx.git
   cd yolo-onnx
   ```
2. Install dependencies:
   ```bash
   pip install -r requirements.txt
   ```
3. Install the package:
   ```bash
   pip install -e .
   ```

## Verify Installation
```python
import yolo_onnx
print(yolo_onnx.__version__)  # Should print: 0.1.0

### docs/getting-started/quickstart.md
A quickstart guide to demonstrate basic usage.

```markdown
# Quickstart

Get started with YOLO-ONNX in just a few steps.

## Step 1: Install YOLO-ONNX
```bash
pip install yolo-onnx

docs.title: Step 2: Prepare a Model
docs.text:
Export a YOLO11 model to ONNX format using Ultralytics: 

yolo export model=yolo11n.pt format=onnx

docs.title: Step 3: Run Inference
docs.text:
from yolo_onnx import YOLOONNX

# Load model
model = YOLOONNX("yolo11n.onnx")

# Run inference
image_path = "image.jpg"
results = model.predict(image_path, conf=0.25, iou=0.7)

# Display results
results[0].show()

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Explore advanced usage in Running Inference.
  • Check out Examples for more use cases. ```

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Explore practical examples to learn how to use YOLO-ONNX.

docs.title: Demo Script
docs.text:
Run the demo script included in the repository: 

python examples/demo.py
See examples/demo.py for the source code.

docs.title: Jupyter Notebook
docs.text: Check out the interactive notebook: - demo.ipynb

docs.title: Custom Use Case
docs.text:
Create your own script: 

from yolo_onnx import YOLOONNX

model = YOLOONNX("yolo11n.onnx")
results = model.predict("custom_image.jpg")
results[0].save("custom_output.jpg")

docs.title: Running Inference
docs.text: Learn how to use YOLO-ONNX to run inference on images.

docs.title: Basic Inference
docs.text:
from yolo_onnx import YOLOONNX

# Initialize model
model = YOLOONNX("yolo11n.onnx")

# Run inference
results = model.predict("image.jpg", conf=0.25, iou=0.7)

# Display results
results[0].show()

docs.title: Customizing Inference
docs.text:
• Confidence Threshold: Adjust conf to filter detections (e.g., conf=0.5).
  • IoU Threshold: Set iou for non-maximum suppression (e.g., iou=0.6). 
    results = model.predict("image.jpg", conf=0.5, iou=0.6)

docs.title: Saving Results
docs.text:
Save detection results to a file: 

results[0].save("output.jpg")
